snippet: The Metro-North train that derailed in the Bronx on Sunday, killing four people, had an alert system in place in the locomotive pushing the rail cars, but not in the cab where the train operator was positioned.
abstract: Metro-North train that derailed in the Bronx, killing four people, had alert system in place in locomotive pushing rail cars, but not in cab on opposite end where train operator William Rockefeller was positioned; appears likely that if Rockefeller had experienced similar episode of inattentiveness on northbound trip, where he would have been stationed in locomotive, the siren might have sounded.

byline.original: By MATT FLEGENHEIMER, FORD FESSENDEN and HENRY FOUNTAIN

lead_paragraph: The Metro-North train that derailed in the Bronx on Sunday, killing four people, had an alert system in place in the locomotive pushing the rail cars, but not in the cab where the train operator was positioned.

headline.main: Train Had a Warning System, Just Not in the Operator’s Cab
headline.print_headline: Train Had a Warning System, Just Not in the Operator’s Cab
